summary: Border vigilante Bill Greer (Frank Grillo) and his son Jackson (Jake Allyn) are on patrol when Jackson accidentally kills a Mexican immigrant boy. Bill tries to take the blame but Texas Ranger Ramirez (George Lopez) sees through the lie, spurring Jackson to flee south on horseback across the Rio Grande to become a gringo "illegal alien" in Mexico. Chased by Texas Rangers and Mexican federales, Jackson journeys across deserts and mountains to seek forgiveness from the dead boy's vengeful father (Jorge A. Jimenez), as he falls in love with the land he was taught to hate.

reviews.content:
The screenplay is the reason this film fails badly. It cannot decide which point of view to present. After beautifully depicting and defining the area between the border and Texas as a dangerous filled with 'coyotes' who may take you across or just as soon kill you, the film becomes "Both Sides Now" in a circuitous, laborious, stultifying, stupefying bore. There are the marauders who cut the rancher's fences, steal his cattle on a regular basis. Defend your land and way of life by pursuing them and come across good, moral, religious people fleeing a life of poverty, hunger and crime for the opportunity in America. 'Bad' escape arrest; 'Good' get hurt or killed. 
The hard-working ranch family become duplicitous, evasive liars, totally ignoring the emotions of the son that did the killing. He speaks, pleads, they ignore his anguish. Foolishly, he runs across the border where he is an emotional wreck and a cultural idiot. WHY? We begin a long, long journey  seeking redemption, but first we must have 'adventures' to show how wonderful the Mexican people really are. The ending violence in which the grotesque coyote is justly killed but all others kiss and makeup is absurd as is the two year prison sentence. A waste of time.
Terrible movie. The fight scenes look extremely fake. There is a cheesy, disgusting love affair and the story line is extremely weak.
Like most stereotypical border (Mexican and American ) movies they have to relate a very human and progressive message while producing a unrealistic story in the process.

A different take to the often cliched genre of a typical Western movie on illegal border crossings from Mexico to America & then vice versa as a young American crosses illegaly into Mexico righting a wrong & seeking redemptionfor his grevious actions. 
Definitely a worthwhile watch with an incredible line up of well known actors in supporting roles.

This thoughtful film could have been a minor modern epic if it had been given a stronger script. As is, it holds interest until some poorly developed story details begin to become too obvious. It's also photographically patchy, with cheap handheld shots bringing down the better-constructed sequences. Some distracting editing in the first half won't help it gain the attention the overall story is straining for – a pity because the whole thing has very good intentions as we follow a young man's attempts to redeem himself for an accidental killing. 

Performances are sincere with the casting generally convincing, it's just the weak moments in the script that let it down. Music is well used throughout including a couple of interesting songs and the outdoor locations standing in for the Tex-Mex border add impact – those who don't feel the need to analyze their entertainment won't mind the flaws, others may be let down.
It didn't suck.  Well paced build-up that keeps it's focus throughout.
Too much of a message movie for me. And I might have snoozed off, I didn't much care by the end. But I've seen worse.

I loved this movie because it showed how wrong you can be of others not like you. And in the end forgiveness! People are so judgmental of Mexicans crossing the border when in reality they are some of the first people here and they worked to make  our country what it is. And this young man tried his best to right his wrong.
A lovely film, beautiful atmosphere, good acting.
Very tedious and just not believable.  We couldn't watch it all and turned it off half way through.
An entertaining movie with a good message and talented cast. A good watch if you're a fan of westerns and are looking for a modern take on the genre.

This movie is trash. It does a terrible job of addressing issues at the border between land owners and illegal immigrants who trespass on their property. So many things in this movie just don't make any sense and would never happen that way.
While it covers a timely topic, it lacks nuance and feels contrived, as if told from a privileged perspective that could not possibly understand.

I believe it covers more than justice, redemption, understanding; it fulfills your soul with values such as family, be someone else from a different perspective.
Cast and Frank Grillo are amazing.

I loved the movie! It was so well written and such a moving story. The actors were great as well. Jake Allyn did a great job of portraying a young man affected by conflict at the border, and Frank Grillo never disappoints. I love that westerns are becoming popular again. I would love to see a sequel.
Loved it times a million!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Not realistic and condescending toward Mexican people. Texans rely on Mexicans to break wild horses, not the other way around. Virtually all Anglo landowners in the Rio Grande Valley where this is supposed to take place speak Spanish very well or fluently. Hero of story knows as little Spanish as someone from Maine.

Felt like a college film project or a hobby film by someone wealthy enough to leave their day job and take a detour into film making. Manufactured unrealistic and irrational situations in an attempt to make its audience feel desperation and vulnerability. But instead of being hooked by those emotions at key points (as you normally would in a good thriller or action), you are pushed away by the dullness and unlikely foundations used to trigger such emotions. I found myself wanting to turn this off in the early stages of the movie and move on to something else but there was enough there to "give it 15 more minutes". You end up watching the rest of the movie with this feeling until it finally ends in a predictable and unremarkable manner. While there are real issues at the Texas-Mexico border, for the ranchers who live there and for those in Mexico wanting to cross, the creators of this film didn't strike me as having enough experience with the border or ranching to really hit the bulls eye here (small example - a ranch kid would never drink from the Rio Grande River or be bothered by cactus. There are so many examples like this but will not spoil the more meaningful contradictions). In any event, there were many contradictions like this that unintentionally undermined the character's role,  preventing you from being hooked. There is substantial movie worthy plots at the border, but like a tumbleweed, this one blows with the wind.

I think the movie is genuine. Shows the struggle between two sides where the difference in right and wrong is drawn in the sand and/or a border. And throughout the entire film you're questioning, "Where do I stand?"
Good movie to watch with your family and friends.

This was such a great film!! I just stumbled across it and didn't know what to expect. So glad I did. I was moved emotionally and it held my attention the entire time. Wonderful acting by Jake Allyn, George Lopez, Jorge Jimenez!!! Great story! Glad to see such a good film without the gratuitous sex scenes. Great directing by Connor Allyn.  If you want to see a modern twist on a Western, check it out. Powerful message. Perfect title for the movie. I really did appreciate this film and loved the soundtrack!!!
Dude, this movie is awesome. Everyone should see it. My parents and my sister loved it and usually we never like the same thing. I loved every minute.
beautiful movie, like motorcycle diaries meets no country for old men meets all the pretty horses. much better than news of the world
Dang, I loved this flic! I dug the story of an American illegal alien on the run in Mexico, way to put the shoe on the other foot! Donald Trump needs to watch this movie.
It's about time a movie showed Mexico and the border like it really is! This movie is so authentic and fair, yet has a great exciting story. Just loved this movie!
Superb story and great characters, no one was really all bad or all good, everyone had redeeming qualities, even if they made tragic mistakes or even sins ... like real life!

I thought this was one of the best movies I've seen lately.
Our whole family, 3 generations, watched it together and
everyone gave it a resounding "two thumbs up!"

Amazing movie. I am not usually that into Westerns but this was more of a modern thriller story turned into a deeper drama about Texas and Mexican families in conflict at the border. WAY better than I expected, such a good motion picture. Five stars.

I enjoyed this movie a lot. great acting and such an involving storyline that reeled you in from the start and then never let you go. I will recommend this to all my friends and family, just wonderful.

I was so surprised at how great this movie was! The main guy playing the cowboy who runs off to Mexico is a great young actor (and I'm totally in love with him, he's to die for!) The whole cast is great and the story really original and touching. Super movie.
Really great movie with action, suspense and a powerful message about Mexico and immigration. It truly changed the way I see this whole situation. Love this film.

What I liked about the movie was the story, which showed the life at the border between Texas and Mexico. There was also the tension that many felt against the immigrants as they fear the immigrants might steal food from their farm. Then, the cinematography was pretty good in showing the desolate area. 

However, this movie has many problems. First was the pacing, which was too slow at many scenes. This dragged the movie a bit much. Then, besides the victim's father character, the rest of the characters were pretty bland. The acting needs more emotions to create more impact to the movie. 

Overall, a pretty ok Western drama. 6/10
THIS MOVIE ROCKS! Loved Jake Allyn as a cowboy who goes on the run into Mexico as a reverse illegal alien, chased by the awesome George Lopez! Thumbs Up!

this movie really moved me, it's an exciting and cool Western but set today in Texas and Mexico along the border, and the lead is really a great actor, never seen him before but I will watch for his movies from now on!
I just loved this movie. It touched my heart, made me cry, made me laugh, and just really swept me off my feet. (Also I have to admit, Jake Allyn is SO SO HOT!)

No Man's Land is the name for areas where the US border wall/fence and the Rio Grande River do not follow the same line thus the name of this film. The story of families - one living in/near No Man's land in the US and the other trying to get to the US, is a good one. The largest weakness is the main character, Jackson, played by Jake Allyn, who is also the screenwriter and brother of the film's director, Conor Allyn. Jackson is a slack-jawed kid with less personality than Peyton Manning. (He could play young Peyton in a bio-pic for sure.) The story moves with his accidental shooting of a Mexican boy attempting a border crossing and moves along with his attempt to, in an unspoken way, make it right.
You see some interesting and diverse countryside, and a lot of Jackson riding his horse, saying "I don't speak Spanish," and a lot of other things that might happen when the lead and director are siblings and the director won't say, "Bro, give me SOMETHING!"
Too supporting actors who do give something are Esmeralda Pimentel as Victoria, the rancher whose family takes Jackson on as a worker for awhile, and Andrés Delgado, as Luis, the coyote who pops up to divert Jackson's travels. They keep the movie interesting when they are on screen.
No Man's Land passed the time, but it was rather bland.
This was such a great movie! Best modern Western thriller since HELL OR HIGH WATER. Jake Allyn is going to be a big star!

This movie was fantastic, best I've seen so far this year. Great acting, especially by Jake Allyn and George Lopez, but also Jorge Jimenez. Excellent director, Conor Allyn, whose films I will watch from now on!!!

Despite it's lengthy running time and the amount of set-up, everything in this film feels pathetically contrived and unearned. There's a good story here but this isn't it. What really sums it up is the laziness of the scene where the Texan breaks the horse the Mexicans couldn't (which I suspect is the equivalent of a white guy getting on stage at a Jazz club and shouting "you're doing it all wrong!"). It could have worked if he'd really had a hard time but persevered. Instead he just hops the fence, points a few times and that's it. Beware of the audience reviews of this film as the vast majority are from accounts created solely to boost this feeble offering's rating.
Really excellent film, best I've seen so far this winter! Love the main young guy and the message of the film was so powerful. Just a great movie!
It's a classic western border film with solid action and a human side that makes you think. Definitely watch this one. One of my favorites so far this year.
Heartfelt and beautifully shot...well done all around, and Jorge Jimenez is outstanding!!
Great flick, definitely enjoyed this modern day western! Touched on a number of timely topics and thought it was a compelling story line. Would highly recommend!!

Jake Allyn delivers a career shaping performance along side a star studded cast. A thrilling, modern day western about redemption. No Man's Land shines a much needed light on the issues at our southern border, told with passion, courage, and humanity. An absoulte classic!

I really liked this movie.  Gives the feeling of real people involved in modern day conflict along the US Mexican border.  It's an even treatment of victims on both sides of the border.  However most of the time is spent on the Mexican side but this is good because we don't get this view in the US.  I really liked the attention to detail of the small things.  Some critics complain of cliches. Yes there are cliches.  This does not bother me as real people do speak in cliches many times.

I loved this modern day Western. It is timely and I really loved watching Jackson's journey, both physically and as he confronts his own flawed, long held beliefs. George Lopez is excellent as the dead Mexican boy's father. The scenes shot in Mexico are breathtaking. I cannot wait for Jake Allyn's next film.
Wow, easily one of the best films I've seen over the last year. My girlfriend loved it too.

Great modern western. I love that is showed all point of view at the border. The movie wasn't just about American or Mexicans. It was about how everyone is affected by physical and emotional border. And the movie didn't bang you over the head with politics. It was just a real story about real people. And the intensity was so pulsing. Frank Grillo and the kid Jake Allyn really brought it.

The actual critics who reviewed this movie got it right. This is an inspiring tale of redemption that hooks the viewer in and truly makes you feel for characters on both sides of the fence. Thats nearly impossible to do, yet the film-makers here accomplished that. 

Its a must watch. Its topical and fun...and while the middle has a few scenes that are somewhat redundant it just makes you love the characters even more!!

An insightful look at TX/Mexico border issues that's so well done with beautiful Mexican scenery. I was transported and was walking in Jackson Greer's footsteps after his terrible odyssey after a deadly border conflict.

Go see it!
The movie was super suspenseful and was pulling out all of my emotions, it was amazing!

Enjoyable watch.  Emotional thriller showing a new perspective and realistic portrayal of the struggles and less known beauty on both sides of the border.  Glad the ending wasn´t too sugar coated.  Jake does a good job.  Nice camera work / closeup wide angles.  Wish I could see it in the theater but not allowed #COVID.  Will enjoy watching it again on home theater.
Great movie with low budget George Lopez did great worth a watch

The movie starts at the border but you really get to see all of Mexico as the kid goes on the run with his horse into Mexico. Was also rlly awesome to see Frank Grillo and George Lopez in roles SO different from the usual. This whole movie kept breaking stereotypes so there were constant surprises and the final scene had me going through ALL the feels!

Man, one of the best modern westerns I've seen in 20 years! Loved the balance between keeping it a tense thriller and having really strong character and nuanced constantly evolving relationships. I grew up around horses and all the movie horse work was flawless so to see that was just really cool too.

This film was outstanding, everything from the story line, the relationships, to the symbolism. The moments in this movie are so real and watching the emotional impact these moments have on the characters really pull on the heart strings. 

The writing was extremely well done as well as the direction and the acting. Beautiful job, this is a must watch!
Great storyline and easy to watch!

I loved this movie!  It is beautifully acted by newcomer Jake Allyn and
costars Frank Grillo, Andie MacDowell and a compelling rare dramatic
turn from George Lopez.  It's a must see for those seeking a timely story
of heartache, hope, forgiveness, redemption and scenery that will open
your eyes to the beauty of Mexico.
Loved this movie! It was immersive and entertaining; and it lead to some thought provoking conversations around immigration, nationalism and ultimately what it means to be human.

Incredibly well acted and beautifully filmed story about
two families at the Texas Mexico border.  A timely epic
with an abundance of heart.  I strongly recommend!
Such a beautiful movie. It thoughtfully handles a very divisive political issue and illuminates the humanity on both sides. Highly recommend!

Powerful, beautiful, timely: A masterpiece.  Jake Allyn's performance is a revelation, Hollywood's next leading man. Conor Allyn's brilliant direction, George Lopez, Frank Grillo, Andie MacDowell and Jorge Jimenez: A dazzling array! Must see!

Refreshing to see an indie movie (or any movie for that matter) that brings an authentic and genuine story about an important topic in our country (immigration) to life in a way that people on many sides of the issue can relate to and also get pulled into the story.

Thoughtful, thrilling, and beautifully constructed. No Man’s Land is an AWESOME ride. Jake Allyn is a star in the making and is perfectly complimented by a powerful performance from George Lopez. Don’t overlook this one.
great plot and socially aware. must watch.

This is a beautiful, moving and poignant film.  What I really love is that it takes a difficult subject and doesn't give easy answers. There are so many shades of gray. 

The lead is wonderful, as is the whole cast. I'm looking forward to seeing him in more movies. This is an exciting story and I'm so psyched to have watched it on its first day of release!
Incredible performance by Jake Allyn! Authentic story authentic acting, Jake has a bright career ahead of him! He's a dynamic actor/writer/producer! Absolute Must See!
This movie was incredible!! Jake Allyn's performance as Jackson was stunning and blew me away. I cannot wait to see what's next from him.

Best Western I've seen since No Country. 
Script, acting, direction and cinematography coalesce into something truly memorable - not to mention relevant!

I loved the balance between a tense thriller and a compelling movie about real people on both sides of the border. All the horses chases and modern western elements were as good as any western I've seen in years and the ensemble cast of George Lopez, Andie MacDowell and Frank Grillo really brought it! 100% suggest it!
Quite cool man great action and clever
